name: Ares
subtitle: God of War, Bloodlust, and Violent Conflict
description: Ares, the Greek god of war, embodies the brutal, violent, and bloody aspects of armed conflict - the physical valor and savage thrill of battle that stands in stark contrast to Athena's strategic wisdom and measured warfare. Son of Zeus and Hera, Ares was paradoxically one of the Twelve Olympians yet the least loved among them, his own father Zeus declaring him the most hateful of all the gods. Where Athena represented the intellectual and civilized dimensions of warfare, Ares personified war's chaos, destruction, and indiscriminate slaughter. He delighted in the carnage of battle, often appearing on the battlefield surrounded by his terrifying retinue: Deimos (Terror), Phobos (Fear), Eris (Discord), and Enyo (Destruction). Despite his divine power, Ares was frequently humiliated in myth - wounded by mortal heroes, caught in an affair with Aphrodite, and defeated by Athena and Heracles. The Greeks, who admired cunning and restraint, viewed Ares's uncontrolled fury with ambivalence, yet recognized him as an essential and inescapable aspect of human existence.

sections.Origins: Ares's origins place him firmly within the Olympian family as the legitimate son of Zeus and Hera, though some traditions suggest Hera conceived him alone using a magical herb, mirroring Zeus's solo parentage of Athena. Unlike most Olympians who had specific birth myths and origin stories, Ares seems to have always existed as a primordial force of violence. His name may derive from the Greek word 'are' meaning 'bane' or 'ruin,' and was used as a common noun meaning 'battle' or 'slaughter.' The Spartans claimed special devotion to Ares, and Thebes was associated with his worship through the myth that his serpent-son guarded the spring where Cadmus founded the city.
sections.Mythology: Greek mythology consistently portrays Ares in an unflattering light. In the Iliad, he fights for the Trojans but is wounded by the mortal Diomedes with Athena's help, fleeing back to Olympus 'screaming like nine or ten thousand warriors.' His affair with Aphrodite, wife of Hephaestus, led to public humiliation when the smith-god trapped them in an unbreakable net and displayed them to the mocking Olympians. Ares fathered numerous children, many inheriting his violent nature - including the Amazons through his union with Harmonia, and the brutal Thracian king Diomedes (different from the Greek hero) who fed his horses human flesh. Heracles defeated Ares's son Cycnus and wounded the god himself when Ares tried to intervene. The story of Ares killing Poseidon's son Halirrhothius for raping his daughter Alcippe led to the first trial on the Areopagus ('Hill of Ares'), establishing Athenian judicial traditions.
sections.Role: Within the Greek divine hierarchy, Ares occupied an essential but conflicted position. As war was an inescapable reality of Greek life, he required acknowledgment even if he inspired little love. He represented the aspects of combat that Greeks feared: mindless bloodshed, uncontrollable rage, and destruction without purpose. His retinue of Terror, Fear, Discord, and Destruction personified war's psychological and social devastation. Soldiers might pray to Ares before battle, but Athena received more consistent worship as goddess of strategic victory. Ares's association with Thrace, considered a barbaric land by Greeks, reinforced his identity as representing the uncivilized aspects of warfare that Greeks preferred to project onto others.
sections.Legacy: Ares achieved far greater prominence under his Roman identity as Mars, becoming the father of Romulus and Remus and one of Rome's most honored deities. The Roman Mars combined Ares's warrior aspects with agricultural functions, representing the soldier-farmer ideal. The month of March (Martius) and the planet Mars bear his name. In astrology, Mars governs aggression, competition, and masculine energy. Modern psychology uses 'Ares' to describe personality types characterized by action, aggression, and physical prowess. The god appears throughout Western literature and art, from Renaissance paintings to contemporary fantasy, often representing the destructive potential within humanity. The Areopagus in Athens, associated with his trial, remained a significant judicial and political institution for centuries.

sections.content: The fierce god of war in its brutal aspect - bloodshed, violence, and the chaos of battle. Unlike Athena who represents strategic warfare, Ares embodies raw physical aggression and the savage thrill of combat.
